facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 3, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 332 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: B. Agarwala and K. P. Gupta for the appellant. G. Patwardhan,

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Bachawat, J.

facts.text: Appellant, respondent and two other persons carried on business in partnership under the name Nayagaon Farm.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the respondent and two other persons carried on business in partnership under the name and style of Nayagaon Farm.

facts.text: Respondent was the managing partner and in charge of the partnership assets.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was the managing partner and was incharge of the partnership assets.

facts.text: The firm was dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: The firm was dissolved and a suit was instituted by the appellant

facts.text: Suit instituted by appellant for taking accounts of the dissolved firm.

anchor.surface_text: and a suit was instituted by the appellant for the taking of the accounts of the dissolved firm.

facts.text: Final decree passed in the suit in favour of appellant against respondent for Rs. 17,143/11/0 and Rs. 3,171/6 on account of company's.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually a final decree was passed in the suit in favour of the appellant against the respondent for Rs. 1 7,143 /1 I /0 and Rs. 3,171 /6 as on account of companyts

facts.text: Appellant applied for execution of the decree by arrest and detention of respondent in prison.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied for execution of the decree by arrest and detention of the respondent in prison.

facts.text: In affidavit supporting application, appellant relied on grounds in clauses a and b of proviso to s.51 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: In this affidavit in support of the application, the appellant relied upon the grounds mentioned in clauses  a  and  b  of the proviso to s. 51 of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908.

facts.text: At hearing, those grounds not pressed; counsel relied on clause c of proviso to s.51 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the application those grounds were number pressed but his companynsel relied upon the ground mentioned in cl.  c  of the proviso.

facts.text: Clause c of proviso to s.51 empowers court to order detention if decree for sum judgment debtor bound in fiduciary capacity to account.

anchor.surface_text: By cl.  c  of the proviso to s. 51, the companyrt is empowered to order execution of a money decree by detention of the judgment debtor in prison if it is satisfied that the decree is for a sum for which the judgment debtor was bound in a, fiduciary capacity to account.

facts.text: Executing court held provisions of cl.c satisfied and issued warrant for arrest of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The executing companyrt held that the provisions of cl.  c  were satisfied and issued a warrant for the arrest of the respondent.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court set aside the executing court's order on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court of Allahabad, set aside this order. The decree holder number appeals

facts.text: Decree holder appeals to this court under certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The decree holder number appeals to this companyrt under a certificate granted by the High Court.

holdings.text: Partnership itself does not create a fiduciary relation between the partners or make one of them a trustee for the other or for his representatives. The relation may, however, arise on the death of one of them or be created by other special circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether a fiduciary relation exists between, the partners, the law is stated thus in Halsburys Laws of England 3rd Edition, Vol. 38, art. 1363, p. 820 Partnership itself does number create a fiduciary relation between the partners

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopted from Halsbury's Laws of England and affirmed as consistent with Indian Partnership Act 1932 and Indian Trusts Act 1882

holdings.text: This statement of law is consistent with the provisions of the Indian Partnership Act 1932 and the Indian Trusts Act 1882.
